title: Woolies rips off the very staff behind sales surge
text:
Chief executive Brad Banducci is right to unreservedly apologise to his staff for an underpayment scandal that could see 5700 salaried staff owed as much as $300 million, depending what Woolworths finds as it goes back over nine years and 11 million records.

The staff affected include store managers, deli managers and fresh produce managers.

The underpayment issues stem from when these staff have worked outside regular hours, effectively bringing them under the auspices of the general award – so working late or early, or finishing one night and rushing back in the next morning without a long break.

In other words, those hit are the in-store generals of the Woolworths arm, who have been central to executing the turnaround under Banducci, which on Wednesday helped to deliver record quarterly like-for-like sales growth of 6.6 per cent in the September quarter.

There’s no doubt the awards system – and particularly its interlay with salary arrangements for individual staff – is complex.

Woolworths joins a long list of otherwise good corporate citizens – other recent examples include Qantas, Thales, Super Retail Group (twice) and Wesfarmers’ Bunnings chain – to make costly and embarrassing mistakes.

But Woolworths is a company that every day solves complex problems, like getting mangoes from Darwin to a store in Hobart to a family’s front door steps – not to mention pays its taxes and its executives.

It’s hard to get away from the conclusion that Woolworths simply hasn’t invested the care, attention and resources that it has invested in areas such as price and service, in-store promotions and digital.

Advertisement

All of these factors were reflected in Woolworths’ bumper September quarter numbers. Not only did its Lion King collectables promotion deliver strong growth in comparable transactions, items per basket and overall items, but online sales came in at a staggering 43.2 per cent, suggesting Woolworths' digital strategy is accelerating.

Even Big W looked good, continuing its recent momentum with comparable sales growth of 4.4 per cent - double the same rate for the December quarter last year.

No doubt the market will focus on that sales result, and ignore Woolworths’ pay problems.

But quite appropriately, a chastened Brad Banducci certainly wasn’t taking a victory lap on Wednesday.
description: It’s hard to get away from the conclusion that Woolworths simply hasn’t invested the care, attention and resources in paying staff properly as it has in growing sales.
